review_title: Wonderful place to work - My team are the best though, so I am very biased!
job_title: Executive Personal Assistant in Manchester, England
pros:
In my current team the SLG are actively striving to cultivate a clear career progression track for employee's.

They want you to evolve and stay with the business and create space and opportunities to do so. I feel like the business is always evolving also.

I know my direct line manager and my team add to the fact I enjoy my job so much. They really support new starters and encourage you to ask questions.
I have only been here few months and went from Temp to Perm in that time.

Everyone I have interacted with is warm and friendly and in general.
Although it is a reflection of my team leaders influence on the team I do also believe that energy is an extension of and a reflection of MMU.

I feel supported and I feel they try to be as flexible as professionalism will allow.
I enjoy the option of hybrid working and believe I would be supported in any efforts to progress.
I would recommend a job here to anyone. (FYI- I am picky too).
I have worked at the GMC and The University of Manchester but I feel the environment here is one where I won't have to search for a new job in two years.
I feel at MMU my value is recognised and I will have the best career trajectory.
cons: IT services for new starters is slow but that is the case in every business -In my experience.

review_title: Greedy approach at MMU in past years is really impacting staff on all levels
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Manchester City Centre, England
pros:
Most of the people working in professional services are great and friendly . 
I suppose job security is a factor that makes a lot of people stay.
Most members of staff, unless in management positions don't have to work overtime or take work home, somewhat good work-life balance.
cons:
Very low pay and very little acknowledgement of the cost of living crisis (the yearly salary increase for 22/23 was insulting). 

No reward for employee loyalty, departments tend to at times prioritise employing and training new people up rather than helping existing, loyal employees further their careers. 

A ridiculous amount of fixed-term contracts. Contracts are renewed very close to their end date by HR which causes a lot of talented people to feel as if they were disposable. No focus on helping people progress, having to go through the exact same process as outsiders to apply for different roles. Most likely, when a role is advertised - the team advertising it internally already has someone in mind for the role so interviews will just be them going through the motions. 

When you first start, you are made to think that it is a meritocracy, but with time you will learn that usually, the person who has been there the longest progresses regardless of other factors. Moving to a better paying grade usually takes 2-3 years and the grades and overall pay do not keep up with inflation so by the time you would have made it to a good position, that salary will most likely have been considered comfortable 4-5 years ago but won't be enough to make up for the demands of the role today. 

All teams across Professional Services have been operating in 'fire-fighting' mode throughout the pandemic with one member of staff doing the job of at least 2. Things only appeared to be getting worse as HR refuses to acknowledge more people are needed for business as usual. 

Additionally, it does not help that the university constantly accepts more students in every years' cohorts for which it does not have the facilities to appropriately host (regardless of how many new buildings are built), but the student to staff ratio is only getting worse year by year and staff both across the academic and professional services are more burnt out than ever.

pros: Good colleagues to work with.
cons: A common position, nothing to complain.

review_title: Graduate School - DO NOT WORK THERE
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Manchester City Centre, England
pros: Colleagues at officer level and below are great to work with
cons:
management are ridiculous, no communication, over-worked, stress levels through the roof, not enough staff, wont get more staff, staff looking to leave all the time. Have been told several times - things have to completely break down before new staff is recruited - this is from several areas in the University (including the Graduate School). Management do nothing or take forever to do anything that will actually genuinely help both students and academics, even when the work is done for them - they wont agree to complete - ie. update the website with FAQs

In general, horrible place to work - do not recommend at all.

job_title: Officer in Manchester City Centre, England
pros: The wage was good and went up in yearly increments The job was interesting and lots of development opportunities Good staff benefits and flexible working Good office
cons: Management were aware of bullying but did not want to do anything to address it, which resulted in numerous staff going off sick or leaving HR department are slow and incompetent

job_title: Skills Coach in Manchester City Centre, England
pros: Got to wear a lanyard
cons: Part time staff not part of the “Inclusive Picture” :( Challenge or question status quo at peril. Pyramid syndrome with little opportunity for those at the base to be listened or heard. yes…. We hear you but ! A Grey building, with grey walls and uncreative grey thinking….. if you are an individual, seek the Light, colour and character. Life is short you can do more, believe in yourself, look else where.

pros: Benefits Team members Campus environment
cons: Bad management style and senior management in HR. Dictates / doesn’t listen / treats people in own teams unfairly

review_title: What is going on? High turnover, slow HR processes, leak of management, etc.
pros: Good pension scheme and holidays (35 days if grade 8+).
cons:
Do not allow you to work remotely even if you have a role that does not need to be in the office.

There is no time for training and personal improvement because there is always a lot of work to be done. 

Focus too much on the business deliverables and always leave the technical debt and system improvements for later.

Pay is lower than what the market is currently offering. I had a promotion to a new grade one year ago that HR has not processed yet. 

HR is too slow to process the hiring of new professionals as well.

High turnover. I am always helping new people to join the team, and currently, I do not even have a manager. I had two during two years at the university.

job_title: Research Assistant in Manchester City Centre, England

- Lot's of opportunities arise to work on different projects. Having your foot in the door allows for lots of exposure to great researchers in your field
- Access to great resources at the university as a member of staff
cons:
- Pay is slightly lower than other universities in the North West 
- Strict pay policy that means you have to start at the bottom of the pay spine when starting a new role unless you earned more than what the job is offering in a previous role (irrespective of company). This was and has been extremely frustrating when taking on new roles and short fixed term contracts at MMU. As I have been denied the higher pay that a job was being advertised for (which was also a factor in applying) on a second contract because my current pay was lower.

review_title: Going though changes, research obsessed and ignoring what they're good at
job_title: Business Development Manager in Manchester, England
pros: Big organisation, so a lot going on and fairly well organised. The university is trying to move towards a research culture, so staff are graded on research and there is a lot of re-structuring going on for admin and professional services staff. There's lots of opportunity for advancement in certain areas, but teaching staff are increasingly being measured by research so not unless you can perform well there. I work in professional services, where management is rather lacking and people over-worked. They keep losing business development staff because there are no opportunities and nobody cares. Although MMU are best at applied and business areas, they are really not sure where this stands with their new desire to be top of the post 92 universities. Not a bad place, but large workload, which isn't helped by new software systems and not enough admin staff. Generally positive though
cons: HR are terrible though- disorganised and all over the place, if you are going for a job here, or trying to hire anyone, its like pulling teeth

pros: I have nothing to add to this.
cons: If you are not white, english or male, you will struggle in this University. It is not a good employer for BAME staff, particulary if you want to question why you are being treated differently from english colleagues. Massive problem for this organisation and understandable if you look and see no non-white non-english faces on the senior leadership. It's hidden in plain sight and no one does anything about it. The HR department are the same and will stop you complaining about the problem.

pros: Good location - central Manchester with good transport links. Within walking distance of lots of food outlets and the main town, plenty of reasonable hotels nearby suitable for business trips
cons: The HR and finance departments are slow, queries can take weeks to be processed, the HR staff are difficult to deal with, there never seems to be a direct line to call and emails go unanswered for days/weeks. Contracts are often not processed on time, or wouldn't be if they weren't chased up.

pros:
Salary and working conditions are good and if you haven't got any classes you can work at home so your time can be very flexible as long as you get what you need to do, done on time.
Colleagues can be very supportive and friendly.
cons: You work in isolation most of the time and when you first start there is very little support- you need to pester, pester, pester to get to know the system. Line managers are difficult to get to see and not very supportive favourising some people over others. Some people rise up the pay scales not doing very much and others work very hard with little reward.

job_title: Technical Services Manager in Manchester City Centre, England
pros: I worked at MMU for 11 years and found it a very supportive place to work. No two days were the same. There was access to training for both me and the Team and my Manager had an open door policy. My immediate Manager was incredibly supportive and, along with my peer Manager group we worked as a Team and played to our strengths. As a member of a team of 60 Technicians, under my Manager's leadership, we became the "can-do" example of the University.
cons: Commuting from Wigan is just far enough but you see a different side to people on public transport!

review_title: Generally cushy number, but sucks your will to live. Don't bother reaching for the stars, no reward for it.
pros: All the sick leave and lateness you can eat. Lots of holidays, flexible working hours. Easy location to reach in the city centre, good pension scheme.
cons: Management are very autocratic, not interested in the ideas staff have. Too unionised, everything is a big deal. A slow moving behemoth run by a poor leader and his hand picked coterie of management staff. Too many changes started in one go. Finish one thing before you move on to another! Vice Chancellor's attitude is too bombastic with staff.

review_title: Avoid This University At All Costs
pros: Very little in the way of pros.
cons:
A relatively new senior executive, who value marketisation of UK higher education over education itself, are systematically destroying the work of academics via witless staffing strategies (I believe that redundancies are in the offing) and the use of spurious metrics in order to reduce the university's running costs to the bone. This does not bode well for the future health of the university. I believe parents need to think very carefully before allowing their children to attend this organisation.

(1 star given throughout as the system does not allow for anything less)

pros:
steady rate of pay (increases by £1,000 every year until you reach the maximum for your particular grade / salary band)
positive working environment
excellent awareness and support for those with a disability
very flexible working hours
cons: You get paid on the last working day of the month which can be particularly problematic during Christmas and New Year

pros: I'm somewhat satisfied having studied here as an international student. Great facilities, lots of socialising opportunities both in and outside of the University. Great tutor/lecturer supports and satisfactory guidance throughout the time here.
cons: As an experienced football player, the MMU football team lacks interest and enthusiasm during team try outs, I can say for a lot of friends that not everyone have had enough chances to prove and show their abilities and skills to their full potential. Too many people at each try outs with messy organisation of events, reducing game times for a lot of people. Sadly, my love for the game has been lessen.

pros:
Stable wage, some great colleagues
Some support towards cpd
cons:
Some really poor colleagues who aren't fit for purpose
They work you very hard- the workload model is nearly impossible to understand. 
Research aspirations without giving you the time to research
Some inept management
Instances of bullying from middle management
Large teaching / seminar groups
Red brick aspirations with poly mentality

review_title: Worst place I have ever worked
pros:
Holidays and extra days off at Christmas
Location – reasonably close to train stations
General public sector perks like flexible working arrangements, pension, sick pay etc.
cons:
Bullying culture
Favoritism
Minimal training – PDR process is a total joke and seems like lip service each year
Incompetent middle management
Disconnect between middle management and the people above them and below them
Job titles don’t reflect job roles
Any good staff get frustrated and end up leaving or just stop caring – perpetuating the problems above

review_title: Poorly run organisation that lets down the student experience
pros: The school of art/university has a diverse student cohort. The energy and passion is evident throughout the campus. It's located in a great place very near the city centre and transport links are well placed and convenient. The School of Art has some fantastic facilities, including old and new technology.
cons:
I didn't have a positive start or end to my brief time working here as a term time only employee. The HR department is in disarray and my contract and working hours were not clearly identified when I started work. I had to actively hound HR in order to find out what my entitlements and benefits were. Fast forward to the last week of the academic year and I was told that I owed extra hours that had to be worked off during the summer (I was term time only). 

There are significant issues in the department I worked in (somewhere within the School of Art). Communication is minimal and there's not much done to ensure that everyone is on the same page. Very often important information wasn't circulated amongst team members, messages were often in the form of one line emails or verbal mentions. This resulted in the team being very reactive, inefficient and reliant on ad hoc problem solving - which isn't bad in itself, but the department is primarily a busy counter service and this had an adverse effect on the service provided. 

The team doesn't work as a unit, but rather, as a group of individuals who work on their own. This had a negative impact on the day and night shifts, seasonal events (such as degree shows) and the overall experience of working in the department. As result, the service we were providing to students (and staff) could be incredibly slow, frustrating and fractious. The team have settled into bad habits and certain staff members were able to hide behind admin work at times, creating the illusion that they were working when basically they weren't pulling their weight. Some team members have been working here for so long that they've been ignored and left to do what they please, unmonitored. This invites an attitude of apathy and laziness.

A massive problem is the team's attitude: They can be aloof, arrogant and disrespectful towards both students and fellow staff. Incoming queries and emails were often treated as inconveniences. Certain students and staff were singled out as "trouble" - a huge problem considering this department is supposed to offer technical support and assistance. At the worst times, the team and the department was a hinderance and an obstacle for a student trying to organise a project, or a staff member trying to book out a TV. 

All in all, I became incredibly frustrated with the team. Even the most basic things took a long time to address (it took 9 months for me to be added to a team calendar. It took 9 months to get a t-shirt that fit. It took 9 months for my contract and working hours to get finalised). Worst of all, when I took my concerns to my manager (who actually listened and took everything I said on board), I was reassured that all of these issues would be mitigated with the introduction of a new computer system and team member., which was just another way of passing the buck and not facing the real issues.

review_title: Great staff stifled by poor leadership and senior management promoting sel-interest.
pros: Lot's of great staff wanting and trying to make a difference.
cons: Generally managers only concerned about self-interest.  If you're not a sycophantic "yes person" they'll find a way to get rid of you or make your life hell until you leave.  Lots of incestuous relationships.  HR a total waste of space and an insult to their profession.

pros: Absolutely top rate colleagues to work with who are committed to doing the very best they can for students. A really friendly atmosphere.
cons: Recent changes in senior management have further embedded some of the problem issues of sexism, favouritism and personal agendas. There seems to be an inclination to increase silo working rather than collaboration.

pros:
I was internally recruited on to the Student Journey Transformation Programme which has been a fantastic career development. A great culture to work in where your work really is about improving student and staff experience. This team focused on employing staff from within BAU, so there have been a lot of learning and training opportunities. 
Access to brilliant campus facilities.
Guaranteed pay rises + inflation
35 days holiday plus bank holidays plus Christmas
cons: None that are worth mentioning :)

review_title: A fantastic workplace full of creative, imaginative and positive people
pros: Positive and polite staff and a genuine sense of providing something world class. Great IT and technology with some really modern buildings.
cons: As with any organisation there are some long serving staff who don't like the fact that it isn't what it used to be but there aren't too many of them.

review_title: Much changed and not for the better
pros: Good team spirit even though working without any support from the department's senior managers
cons:
Senior  manager who could not build or develop the department
No consistency in decision making
Poor communications
Blame culture - individuals targeted who then departed
Fear amongst middle/senior managers that they would be next

job_title: Lecturer in Manchester City Centre, England
pros: You may end up working with some inspirational colleagues
cons: You'll be dealing with a lot of non traditional students, and depending on which department you end up in depends on your overall experience. No room for progression unless you tick ALOT of the right boxes.

job_title: Talent Acquisition Specialist in Manchester, England
pros: Amazing place to work. Flexible working and finish at 4.30 everyday. Everyone is really friendly and helpful. Not micromanaged and given full reign of my desk. Everyone at all levels are approachable. Lots of opportunities to progress within the company. Great benefits and brilliant pension scheme. Favourite place to work by far.
cons: No cons that I can think of

pros:
Flexible hours.
Meeting new people every shift.
Food provided during the shift.
cons:
They will employ anyone and everyone.
Middle management are incompetent and ineffective leaders.
Some of the supervisors are too nervous to even speak to subordinates or organize breaks.
Insufficient warm clothing and made to stand in the cold for long periods.

review_title: The best work environment I've had

pros:
Incredible team unity
Very high investment in resources for team and the wider staff
Excellent management ethos
Wide range of employee support schemes
Forward thinking, forward moving organisation that's easy to be proud to work for
Remote working is implemented very well
Exemplary equality & diversity practices
cons:
Site location can be difficult to navigate
Gaining access to new resources/licences/areas can be laborious

job_title: Multi Skilled Maintenance Engineer in Manchester, England
pros: Clean warm and dry place of work, comfortable surroundings and all amenities good, generally pleasant place of work.
cons: University have a massive Manager and supervisor staff, who are not accountable for their specific role,  pay scale is in the middle to low range.

review_title: Not for ambitious one, good for work/life balance
pros: Stress free and clean work environment, friendly and supportive colleagues.
cons: Slow to adapt to the latest in the technology. A bit of chaos in managing the IT infrastructure.

pros: Christmas holidays and short days.
cons: Honestly the worst place I have ever worked. Lack of moral. No proper training or communication. No progression. They don't seem interested in retaining talent, which means they don't invest in you or your career so all of the good people go. This is the place to go if you don't want to feel challenged and like leaving the office at 4:30. Ideal to join during middle age and stay until you retire.

pros: Colleagues are supportive and stimulating. It's an ambitious environment where innovation is supported.
cons: There's some resistance to change and a sense that if something has been tried once, it won't work again.

pros: Some excellent people, decent networking opportunities. Some great teachers who really care for the students.
cons:

Too reactionary to massive data sets (which mean very little).

pros: A lot of resources at disposal

cons: Make sure you are able to suck up to the VC. Do not question management or you will be branded a troublemaker. HR pointless.

pros: Some academic freedom and flexibility.
cons: Management driven by ludicrous metrics. Changes are decided on without consultation and without thinking them through, and often reversed after a year or two.

pros: Colleagues were generally great to work with. The availability of technology for teaching purposes was excellent compared to the majority of the competition.
cons: The pace of change was extremely slow at that time although I believe that has now change for the better. Overly bureaucratic in nature and quite political.
